awd_titl_txt: Estimating the Long-term Effects of Active Learning on Undergraduate Student Learning Outcomes in Microeconomics Courses
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to serve the national interest in high quality undergraduate STEM education.  Specifically, it intends to generate new knowledge about the impact of active learning on long term retention of knowledge.  It also will examine the impacts of active learning on student learning in economics. Two educational conditions motivate this project.  First, the field of economics lags behind other STEM disciplines in the implementation of active learning pedagogies in undergraduate courses and is in need of evidence about the impacts of active learning in undergraduate economics courses.  Secondly, there is limited research on the impact of active learning on the retention of knowledge over the long term.  Building on work supported by an active learning initiative at Cornell University, the project team will examine whether active learning pedagogies improve the learning and long-term retention of core concepts in economics.  The investigation is designed to compare the retention of knowledge about key economics concepts under two conditions: a lecture only format and an active learning format.  The quantitative study will examine how teaching methods (lecture only, active learning), student characteristics, and intervening course and work choices interact to affect post-course student learning outcomes.  

For this project, both introductory and intermediate microeconomics courses at Cornell University will be analyzed with regard to active learning implementation and outcomes. Four research questions guide the study: (1) How much do students retain in the years after course completion?  (2) What role does active learning pedagogy play in students’ retention of learning? (3) What role do demographic characteristics, student work, and educational choice play in the retention of learning? And (4) How do active learning methods affect outcomes (e.g., attitudes, performance in subsequent courses, career choices) that are not directly related to the course in which the methods are used?  To assess classroom activity, faculty and student activity in classrooms will be assessed using the Classroom Observation Protocol for Undergraduate STEM courses instrument.  Students’ knowledge will be assessed after course completion and again one or two years later using the Principles of Economics Skills Assessment for Microeconomics and the Intermediate Economics Skills Assessment for Microeconomics.  In addition, surveys will measure student attitudes towards economics and career plans. Using a pre-post longitudinal design that includes three repeated measures and regression analyses (one cohort is subject to lecture only and subsequent cohorts to active learning), the study will test the efficacy of active learning to improve the retention of core economic concepts when compared to learning outcomes from a lecture only condition.   The NSF IUSE: EHR Program supports research and development projects to improve the effectiveness of STEM education for all students.  Through the Engaged Student Learning track, the program supports the creation, exploration, and implementation of promising practices and tools.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The vast majority of research on student learning is based on assessments of student knowledge given during or at the end of an academic term. Until now, we have known very little about what students retain in the years after a course is over or what determines how much they retain. The major goals of this project were to fill this gap and answer three substantive questions:

              1. How do active learning methods and online instruction affect student outcomes in the long-term relative to in-person lecturing with minimal student activity in the classroom?

              2. How do students with different characteristics and from different groups retain what they learned in a course in the years after a course is over?

              3. How do intervening work and course choices affect post-course outcomes, especially learning retention?

To address these questions, we started by collecting data from over one thousand students who took two economics courses (Introduction to Microeconomics and Intermediate Microeconomics) that were taught recently using an in-person pure lecture approach in one semester and with active learning methods and/or online instruction in two additional semesters. At the end of each of the six semesters, we measured student skills with a standard assessment and collected demographic information. We followed up with these students one or 1.5 years after course completion, and then again one year later. During each follow-up data collection period, students completed the same standard assessment of the skills that they were given at the end of the course and a survey about their academic and job-related choices since the course ended.

Our data analysis involved estimating a series of regression models where we compare the skill retention of students in the same courses taught in different ways, controlling for a wide range of student characteristics and behaviors. We find that students on average score lower on assessments at follow-up relative to the end of the term, but this decline varies significantly depending on how the courses were taught, student demographics, and student behavior during the period between the end of the course and the follow-up.

We find some significant positive effects of active learning in both courses that are consistent with theory suggesting that students learn concepts at a deeper and more permanent level when they actively engage with the material in the classroom. The effects of online instruction are not as consistent across courses, but we see no evidence of a negative effect and some evidence that it could be helpful in the intermediate-level course. It’s possible the observed positive effect of online instruction is in part due to students’ lack of distractions from extra-curricular activities which were put on hold during the COVID-19 pandemic.

In both the introductory and intermediate-level courses, we have examined whether gender, underrepresented minority status (URM), first-generation college-goer status, and college major are associated with how much knowledge students retain. In the introductory courses, gender is the only significant predictor with scores of female students declining more than male scores at the one-year follow-up. This effect dissipates by the two-year follow-up. We see somewhat smaller declines for females relative to males in the intermediate-level courses though they are not statistically significant. We also see large statistically significant declines for URM students after 1.5 years though these disappear by 2.5 years. Even though they may not persist, these race and gender differences are worrying, and we are currently exploring and testing plausible explanations.

We see the roles of subsequent economics courses and jobs that apply economics are quite different for students in the introductory and intermediate courses. Later economics courses seem to help students retain information from the introductory course in both follow-ups, and this is consistent with these courses reinforcing what was learned in the original course. Holding a job where they apply economic concepts is not significantly associated with retention of introductory economics skills.

Conversely, courses do not help retention of intermediate-level skills, but we believe that few "advanced" undergraduate economics courses substantially apply or build on the technical skills that are evaluated in the assessment. Students who have jobs during the interim period do in fact retain more skills, but this may in part be due to selection. That is, it is possible that students with strongly held skills are more successful finding jobs where they can apply the economics knowledge. On the other hand, it is possible that working on economics-related topics on the job solidified student understanding.

Perhaps the most important contribution of our project is that we have demonstrated the feasibility of collecting long-term student outcome data, and we hope this will inspire other researchers to see how pedagogy, student characteristics, and student behavior affect long-term learning in other contexts.
